{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Left 4 Dead: The Sacrifice''}} {{Infobox comic | name = Left 4 Dead: The Sacrifice | image = The Sacrifice L4D.png|center | image_caption = Navigational image for ''The Sacrifice'', with each character image linking to one part of the comic. | code = | title_orig = | hero = [[Bill (Left 4 Dead)|Bill]], [[Francis (Left 4 Dead)|Francis]], [[Louis (Left 4 Dead)|Louis]], and [[Zoey (Left 4 Dead)|Zoey]] | appearances = | pages = 178 | layout = | story = The Sacrifice (''[[Left 4 Dead]]'') | ink = [[Michael Avon Oeming]] | date = September 14, 2010 | first = ''The Sacrifice - Part One'' | last = ''The Sacrifice - Part Four'' }} '''''The Sacrifice''''' is a digital [[comic book]] created by [[Valve Corporation]] based on the ''[[Left 4 Dead]]'' video game, detailing the events that the protagonists–Zoey, Louis, Francis, and Bill–experience after the chronological final campaign, ''Blood Harvest''. It accompanies a campaign in both ''Left 4 Dead'' and ''[[Left 4 Dead 2]]'' of the same name. It also serves as a prequel to the campaign from ''Left 4 Dead 2'' called ''The Passing'', which makes allusions to the events.
==Synopsis== ''The Sacrifice'' takes place between the "Blood Harvest" campaign of the main ''Left 4 Dead'' game, and leads up to the events of "The Sacrifice" downloadable campaign for ''Left 4 Dead''. Interspersed within the story are flashbacks showing the events that each Survivor experienced a short time "after First Infection"; watching friends, loved ones, and strangers turn into zombie-like creatures before their eyes and each realizing they are immune to the Infection.<ref>{{Cite comic|cartoonist=[[Michael Avon Oeming]]|story=Left 4 Dead|title=[http://www.l4d.com/comic/ The Sacrifice]|volume=|issue=1-4|date=September 14, 2012|publisher=|location=|page=|panel=|id=}}</ref>
From the end of "Blood Harvest", the four Survivors—Bill, Zoey, Louis, and Francis—are rescued by U.S. Army and taken to Millhaven, a well-fortified army base.<ref>{{Cite comic|cartoonist=[[Michael Avon Oeming]]|story=Left 4 Dead|title=[http://www.l4d.com/comic/ The Sacrifice]|volume=|issue=1|date=September 14, 2012|publisher=|location=|page=|panel=|id=}} "'''Soldier''': ''[after knocking Francis out cold, to the other Survivors]'' Bring your smart ass friend. Anybody that makes a break for it, that body gets shot. Welcome to Millhaven."</ref> They are immediately split up; Francis and Louis are put into an isolation room, while Bill and Zoey are tested by a doctor.<ref>{{Cite comic|cartoonist=[[Michael Avon Oeming]]|story=Left 4 Dead|title=[http://www.l4d.com/comic/ The Sacrifice]|volume=|issue=2|date=September 14, 2012|publisher=|location=|page=51|panel=|id=}} "'''Louis''': Wherever we are, it sure ain't Camp Echo. / '''Francis''': Zoey and Bill? / '''Louis''': ''"With the Doctor."'' That's all they'll tell me. ''[...]'' / "'''Annie''': You're in a hermetically-sealed sterile room with an independent ventilation system. The only way we're coming in there is if you are dead or on fire.</ref> All four learn that they are "Carriers", having the virus yet showing no symptoms. Zoey herself is horrified to learn that her father, who requested her to kill him before he turned, had the Carrier gene, meaning that his death could have been avoided. They describe to Lt. Mora how the Infection has mutated to create "Special" Infected with unique abilities.<ref>{{Cite comic|cartoonist=[[Michael Avon Oeming]]|story=Left 4 Dead|title=[http://www.l4d.com/comic/ The Sacrifice]|volume=|issue=2|date=September 14, 2012|publisher=|location=|page=53-54|panel=|id=}} "'''Louis''': ''[speaking to the soldiers guarding them about "mutated" Infected]'' Wait a minute. You guys've never seen a ''Boomer?'' / '''Annie''': ''[a little disbelieving]'' A "Boomer". / '''Louis''': Big fatassed zombies that '''''barf''''' on you. / '''Jeff''': ''[surprised]'' Get the hell outta here. / '''Louis''': Oh, I ain't even ''got'' to the screwed-up part. See, the barf attracts ''other'' zombies. It's like...I dunno, cat nip or something. ''[...]'' But even ''they're'' not the worst ones. There's this thing called a Hunter. They'll leap a hundred off a building, right on ''top'' of you. Rip your guts out with their ''claws''. / '''Annie''': Holy shit... / '''Louis''': Then you got the Tanks. / '''Jeff''': The zombies have ''tanks?'' / '''Louis''': Don't need 'em. These things're thirty feet tall. Arms like ''tree trunks''. They'll pick a boulder up just to ''beat'' you to ''death'' with it."</ref> Though Lt. Mora agrees with the Survivors' reports (having seen the Special Infected himself), his superior, Everly, is highly skeptical, and refuses to take steps to consider evacuating the base despite not receiving orders for the last nine days. Mora becomes concerned that the Survivors may be on the side of the Infected, and privately discusses plans to evacuate the facility.<ref>{{Cite comic|cartoonist=[[Michael Avon Oeming]]|story=Left 4 Dead|title=[http://www.l4d.com/comic/ The Sacrifice]|volume=|issue=2|date=September 14, 2012|publisher=|location=|page=|panel=|id=}}</ref>
[[File:The Sacrifice Comic.jpg|left|thumb|256px|One of the pages from the fourth issue of the comic.]] Mora overthrows Everly and sounds the evac alarm, unintentionally drawing Infected that attack the base, including several Special Infected able to breach the base's defense. As Mora's squad attempt to hold back the Infected; Bill, Zoey, Louis, and Francis, along with two befriended soldiers and a doctor (who is also immune), attempt to make their way to a nearby trainyard to a train south towards Florida. As they are escaping, Mora, injured from battle, attempts to stop the group, believing them responsible for the invasion; but Bill knocks him down. As they discover a train, Everly attempts to escape in a helicopter, but a Tank sends it crashing to the ground. Finding an available train, the group becomes concerned that it has become too quiet, and Zoey suggests there is something lying in wait for them. They are soon attacked by a Tank and a horde of Infected. The two soldiers sacrifice themselves to protect the group as they start the train. While the four Survivors are able to board in time, the doctor lags behind; to Zoey's dismay and anger, Bill refuses to slow down, stating that "we come back for our own".<ref>{{Cite comic|cartoonist=[[Michael Avon Oeming]]|story=Left 4 Dead|title=[http://www.l4d.com/comic/ The Sacrifice]|volume=|issue=3|date=September 14, 2012|publisher=|location=|page=|panel=|id=}}</ref>
As they travel south, Bill explains that his plan is to get them to the islands of the [[Florida Keys]]; as the Infected cannot swim, they will be safe there. At a town at the end of the line, they start searching for a boat. While navigating the town, Zoey explains to Francis that she doesn't understand Bill; Francis says that "Bill doesn't always do the right thing, but he does it for the right reasons".<ref>{{Cite comic|cartoonist=[[Michael Avon Oeming]]|story=Left 4 Dead|title=[http://www.l4d.com/comic/ The Sacrifice]|volume=|issue=4|date=September 14, 2012|publisher=|location=|page=|panel=|id=|quote=<!--'''Francis''': -->}}</ref> Shortly after, they find a yacht, but Louis is severely injured when he finds it packed with Witches. After burning the yacht, the group finds a sailboat, filled with provisions and medicine; however, to get it downriver, they must raise a rusty old bridge blocking their path. They start nearby generators and prepare to fight the horde while waiting for the bridge to be raised, but soon the generators give out. Bill, without pause, jumps off the bridge and makes his way to the generators, restarting them as three Tanks strike him and maul him to death. Francis attempts to go after Bill but Zoey stops him, sadly commenting that Bill's sacrifice will have been for nothing.<ref>{{Cite comic|cartoonist=[[Michael Avon Oeming]]|story=Left 4 Dead|title=[http://www.l4d.com/comic/ The Sacrifice]|volume=|issue=4|date=September 14, 2012|publisher=|location=|page=|panel=|id=}} "'''Zoey''': He did this for ''us.'' If you go down there, he did it for ''nothing.'' / '''Francis''': ''[lowering his head]'' ...god''damn''it."</ref> After waiting for the horde to disperse, the three quietly return to the boat and set course to the Keys.
==History== [[File:Oeming08.jpg|right|thumb|Comic book veteran [[Michael Avon Oeming]] was brought on by Valve in hopes of creating a quality product based on ''Left 4 Dead''.]] The comics were illustrated by [[Michael Avon Oeming]], a comic books veteran.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://new.shacknews.com/file/20824/left-4-dead-comic-the-sacrifice-part-1 |title=Left 4 Dead Comic 'The Sacrifice' Part 1 - Shacknews.com |publisher=New.shacknews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69TlRbcZR?url=http://www.shacknews.com/file/20824/left-4-dead-comic-the-sacrifice-part-1 |archivedate=2012-07-27 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= Richard George |url=http://comics.ign.com/articles/112/1120580p1.html |title=Left 4 Dead Lives On - Comics News at IGN |publisher=Comics.ign.com |date=2010-09-14 |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> Valve stated that the comic was made both because it wants to expand its video games into other mediums, as well as in response to both the critical reception that the ''[[Team Fortress 2]]'' comics received and the commercial sales that the comic led to for ''Team Fortress 2''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/2010/08/21/interview-valve-on-their-new-left-4-dead-dlc/ |title=Interview: Valve reveal their new Left 4 Dead DLC |publisher=PC Gamer |date=2010-08-21 |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> While the plot of ''The Sacrifice'' is canon, its creators [[Valve Corporation]] made a note that they did not want to force the plot into the game; as such, they designed the accompanying in-game campaign to choose how it ends.<ref>{{cite web|author=Words: Tyler Nagata, GamesRadar US |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/pc/left-4-dead/news/left-4-dead-comic-is-canon-says-valve-part-3-of-the-sacrifice-releases/a-2010092921484676004/g-20061120155139282079 |title=‘Left 4 Dead comic is canon,’ says Valve. Part 3 of The Sacrifice releases, Left 4 Dead PC News |publisher=GamesRadar |date= |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> Valve commented that they hated to see video games made into bad films or comics, due to most of them being "disconnected from [the video game's] source", so they decided to make the comic in-house. They commissioned Oeming to illustrate their comic to allow the comic to reach a certain level of quality. While the comic began as smaller than the current size, it grew as they fleshed out certain parts, due to their enjoyment of the characters and their intention to "give each one time in the spotlight." Valve also explains that they feel that comics are a better format for video game adaptations than films; they state that when players get attached to a character, a comic book allows them to appreciate them more than a two-hour film versus spending "hours and hours, even hundreds of hours with them" with them in the video game. They add that comics help to go into stories that the game doesn't elaborate on.<ref name="interview">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsarama.com/games/left-4-dead-comics-interview-101004.html |title=Sacrificing LEFT 4 DEAD With Online Comics |publisher=Newsarama.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref>
Much of the comic's content was created before the comic was created; in particular, the flashback featuring Francis was one of the first thing that was written for him. Valve explains the addition of numerous supporting characters is due to the new format; where the video games only allowed for focus on the main characters, they could go more in depth on others and show the effects of the infection on the rest of the world. When asked why Bill was chosen to die, Valve explained that they wanted the sacrifice to be done by the most impacting and favourite character by both Valve and the community, as well as the fact that his story matched ''The Sacrifice'' well.<ref name="interview"/>
''The Sacrifice'' was released in four parts. Valve released it in both downloadable PDF format or viewable on their web site. They specifically released versions of the comic without text or speech bubbles for the purpose of allowing fans to localize them into other languages. They added that this would allow fans to make their own dialogue for them.<ref name="gr">{{cite web|author=Words: Tyler Nagata, GamesRadar US |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/pc/left-4-dead/news/part-two-of-the-left-4-dead-comic-releases/a-20100922142616969032/g-20061120155139282079 |title=Part two of the Left 4 Dead comic releases, Left 4 Dead PC News |publisher=GamesRadar |date= |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=barichnikov |url=http://www.shacknews.com/article/65709/left-4-dead-sacrifice-dlc |title=Left 4 Dead 'Sacrifice DLC' Comic Part Two Av |publisher=Shacknews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> Valve announced that the best fan-made comics would be featured on the ''Left 4 Dead'' developer's blog.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/2010/09/22/part-2-of-the-left-4-dead-comic-is-out/ |title=Part 2 of the Left 4 Dead comic is out |publisher=PC Gamer |date=2010-09-22 |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> The first part was released on September 14, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|author=Longgshot |url=http://www.shacknews.com/article/65539/left-4-dead-sacrifice-dlc |title=Left 4 Dead Sacrifice DLC Comic Launches Tomo |publisher=Shacknews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> Each following part was released every week following, up until the release of The Sacrifice in the games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.l4d.com/blog/post.php?id=4352 |title=Left 4 Dead Blog |publisher=L4d.com |date=2010-09-14 |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> It was eventually released for the [[IOS (Apple)|iOS]] items [[iPhone]] and [[iPad]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.l4d.com/blog/post.php?id=4493 |title=Left 4 Dead Blog |publisher=L4d.com |date=2010-10-14 |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> When asked whether more comics would be made by Valve, they stated in the affirmative, specifically saying that "this isn’t the last you will see of Left 4 Dead comics."<ref name="interview"/> The full comic was published by [[Dark Horse Comics]] in ''Valve Presents: The Sacrifice and Other Steam-Powered Stories'', a volume along with other comics created by Valve for ''[[Team Fortress 2]]'' and ''[[Portal 2]]'', which was released in November 2011.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/35767/Comic_Book_Based_On_Valve_Strips_Coming_This_November.php | title = Comic Book Based On Valve Strips Coming This November | first = Mike | last= Rose | date = 2011-07-11 | accessdate = 2011-07-11 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] }}</ref>
==Reception== [[GamesRadar]]'s Tyler Nagata commented that, as of the second release, it was "pretty great," praising it for its "snarky dialogue and messy encounters with the special infected".<ref name="gr"/> [[Kotaku]]'s Michael McWhertor recommended it for fans of the series.<ref>http://kotaku.com/#!5638117/left-4-deads-the-sacrifice-goes-live</ref> [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'s Gus Mastrapa praised the beginning of the comic for "capturing the frenetic action of the first-person shooter". He adds that while he prefers that the video games do not go too much into the story, stating that the "mystery makes the action feel that much more visceral", he praised the execution for expanding the narrative in an outside medium without ruining the mystery.<ref>{{cite news|author=<!--start post navigation--> Previous post Next post |url=https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2010/09/left-4-dead-the-sacrifice-2/ |title=Left 4 Dead Comic Tells Story Between Missions | GameLife |publisher=Wired.com |date= 2010-09-15|accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> [[Destructoid]]'s Nick Chester called it "decent hype" for the upcoming ''Left 4 Dead'' campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/left-4-dead-the-sacrifice-comic-hits-tomorrow-183793.phtml |title=Left 4 Dead 'The Sacrifice' comic hits tomorrow |publisher=Destructoid |date= |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> [[PC Gamer]] described them as "thrilling".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/2010/10/06/the-sacrifice-comic-concludes-dlc-out/ |title=The Sacrifice comic concludes, DLC out |publisher=PC Gamer |date=2010-10-06 |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> At the start of the comics' releases, [[Rock Paper Shotgun]]'s Kieron Gillen expressed interest, citing illustrator Michael Avon Oeming's "fantastic" visual storytelling.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2010/09/15/sequential-first-part-the-sacrifice-comic/ |title=Sequential First Part: The Sacrifice Comic |publisher=Rock, Paper, Shotgun |date= |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> With the release of the second comic, fellow Rock Paper Shotgun editor Alec Meer emphatically recommended that readers read it, expressing "mild frustration" with the wait for the next comic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2010/09/22/left-4-dead-not-2-part-2/ |title=Left 4 Dead Not 2, Part 2 |publisher=Rock, Paper, Shotgun |date= |accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref> In a poll of what readers of the comic would like to see ''The Sacrifice'' released in, the choices were, in order of popularity: TV, computer, mobile device, and print.<ref name="interview"/> The supporting characters introduced in the comic have received some positive reception, with Valve citing an email they received asking if Annie, one of the soldiers accompanying the survivors, survived the zombie horde.<ref name="interview"/>

'''Theft from libraries''' is the crime of [[Theft|stealing]] [[book]]s, [[DVD]]s or other media from [[libraries]]. It is typically prevented by installing [[electronic article surveillance]] alarms at the doors. Library materials are tagged and if the tag is not deactivated it sounds an alarm. In some libraries with older or rare materials, readers are not allowed to take coats or bags into the reading area except for a few items in a clear plastic bag.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bl.uk/reshelp/inrrooms/stp/locker/cloakroom.html|title=Help for Researchers: Cloakroom and Lockers|publisher=British Library|accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref> [[Security camera]]s are not commonly used in libraries for privacy reasons.
One study commissioned in the UK estimated the average loss rate of libraries to theft at 5.3%.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=sARvKM5rynkC&pg=PA175&dq=library+theft&hl=en&sa=X&ei=06NcUb_4Kubq0AHCtIDgBQ&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAA Planning Public Library Buildings: Concepts and Issues for the Librarian - Michael Dewe - Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In the U.S. state of [[Pennsylvania]], the third conviction for library theft is a [[felony]], regardless of the value of material.<ref>[http://www.carnegielibrary.org/usingthelibrary/policies/librarytheft.html Pennsylvania Library Theft Act, Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101070711/http://www.carnegielibrary.org/usingthelibrary/policies/librarytheft.html |date=2012-11-01 }}</ref>
Library thieves, who may be staff or regular visitors of the library, risk being discovered if a book is found in the [[library catalog]] but missing from the shelves. To avoid this, some library thieves have been careful to also steal the catalog card describing the book.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22249700 The curious tale of the stolen books], by Martin Vennard for BBC News Magazine, April 24, 2013.</ref>
==Trends== In public libraries, librarians have noticed common themes in what subjects are most frequently stolen. Books with topics like sex and [[witchcraft]] are popular with thieves, as are guides for [[General Educational Development]] testing.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Epstein|first1=Edward|title=U.S. libraries checking out book theft / 'Most-stolen' list will help curb crime|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/U-S-libraries-checking-out-book-theft-2921164.php|publisher=SFGate}}</ref>
In a poll taken in 1996, the top three books that went missing were: ''[[The Joy of Sex]]'', GED Examination Books, and the ''Prophecies'' of [[Nostradamus]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mosley|first1=Shelley|last2=Caggiano|first2=Anna|last3=Charles|first3=John|title=The "Self-Weeding" Collection: The Ongoing Problem of Library Theft, and How To Fight Back.|journal=Library Journal|date=October 15, 1996|volume=121|issue=171|pages=38-40}}</ref>
==Theft incidents== [[Rare books]] departments of libraries especially fall target to professional thieves. In 1996, two rare early Mormon manuscripts were stolen from the [[Public Library of Cincinnati and Hamilton County]], when the thief requested the manuscript and replaced it with a facsimile.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://rbms.info/theft-reports/1996/09/26/two-mormon-publications-stolen/ | title=Two Mormon Publications Stolen | publisher=Association of College & Research Libraries | date=September 26, 1996 | accessdate=18 December 2015}}</ref>
'''Document theft''' is the crime of stealing documents of historical, literary, or cultural interest from public or private archives, often for the purpose of sale to private collectors. In many cases, document thieves occupy positions of trust, or have established records of legitimate accomplishment, prior to their crimes. Examples of notable convicted document thieves include former [[New York State Archives|New York State]] archivist [[Daniel D. Lorello]],<ref>''Albany Times Union'', 7 August 2008</ref> [[Frede Møller-Kristensen]], who between 1968 and 1978 stole some 1,600 historical books worth more than $50 million from the [[The Royal Library, Denmark|Danish National Library]], and antiquities dealer [[Forbes Smiley|E. Forbes Smiley III]], who stole nearly 100 maps from libraries in the United States and Great Britain over the course of eight years.<ref>''New York Times,'' 22 June 2006</ref> In addition to letters, maps, and other manuscript material, rare books also attract the attention of document thieves. [[John Charles Gilkey]], for instance, stole hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of rare books over the course of many years. These crimes were largely the product of a personal obsession, illustrating the range of motives in document thefts.<ref>Bartlett, Allison Hoover (2009). ''The Man Who Loved Books Too Much: The True Story of a Thief, a Detective, and a World of Literary Obsession''. Riverhead. ''{{ISBN|9781594488917}}''.</ref>

'''LinguaSys, Inc.''' was a company headquartered in [[Boca Raton]], [[Florida]]. LinguaSys provided multilingual human language software and services<ref>[http://www.eweek.com/cloud/salesforce.com-marketing-cloud-gains-next-gen-social-analytics/ Salesforce.com Marketing Cloud Gains Next-Gen Social Analytics]</ref> to financial, banking, hospitality, Customer Relations Management, technology, forensics<ref>[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/mobile-forensics-goes-multilingual-as-micro-systemation-taps-linguasys-translation-technology-204684551.html Mobile Forensics Goes Multilingual As Micro Systemation Taps LinguaSys Translation Technology]</ref> and telecommunications blue chip enterprises, and the government and military.
==History== LinguaSys was co-founded by Chief Executive Officer Brian Garr in Boca Raton, Florida, USA;<ref>[http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2012-08-27/business/fl-worker-turned-entrepreneur-20120826_1_google-s-motorola-mobility-ibm-speech-recognition-technology South Florida workers-turned-entrepreneurs are creating jobs - Sun Sentinel]</ref><ref>[http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20130506/COLUMNIST/130509824/-1/news?Title=Angel-investors-ar-eout-there-you-just-need-to-know-where-to-look Angel investors are out there; you just need to know where to look | HeraldTribune.com]</ref> Chief Technology Officer Vadim Berman in Melbourne, Australia; and Vice President of Development and Architecture Can Unal in Darmstadt, Germany in 2010.
CEO Brian Garr was formerly CTO of Globalink from 1995–1998 and is a recipient of the Smithsonian Institute's "Heroes in Technology" award for his work in Machine Translation.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}}
Billionaire [[Mark Cuban]] began investing in LinguaSys, Inc., in 2012.<ref>[http://nibletz.com/2013/05/08/mark-cuban-leads-1-million-dollar-florida-startup-linguasys/ Mark Cuban Leads $1 Million Dollar Round For Florida Startup LinguaSys | Serious Startups<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140105235515/http://nibletz.com/2013/05/08/mark-cuban-leads-1-million-dollar-florida-startup-linguasys/ |date=2014-01-05 }}</ref><ref>http://www.bizjournals.com/southflorida/news/2013/05/03/billionaire-mark-cuban-among-investors.htmlong-investors.html</ref><ref>[https://thenextweb.com/insider/2012/10/10/mark-cuban-backs-human-language-specialist-linguasys/ Dallas Mavericks Owner Mark Cuban Backs Language Specialist LinguaSys]</ref>
Also in 2012, LinguaSys partnered with [[Salesforce.com]], adding multilingual text analytics abilities to the company's social marketing services.
In 2014, LinguaSys made their technology available in a public cloud.<ref>[http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20141021005129/en/LinguaSys-Launches-“GlobalNLP”-Natural-Language-Processing-API LinguaSys Launches “GlobalNLP” Natural Language Processing API Portal for Developers]</ref>
In 2015, LinguaSys added NLUI Server, which enables building Siri-like natural language applications rapidly in a variety of languages, to the products available in the public cloud.<ref>[http://www.speechtechmag.com/Articles/News/Speech-Technology-News-Features/LinguaSys-Launches-Natural-Language-User-Interface-Server-102047.aspx LinguaSys Launches Natural Language User Interface Server]</ref>
In August 2015, LinguaSys was acquired by [[Aspect Software]].<ref>[http://www.aspect.com/company/news/press-releases/aspect-software-announces-acquisition-of-the-technology-assets-of-linguasys-a-leading-provider-of-natural-language-understanding-nlu-and-interactive-text-response-itr-technology Aspect Software Announces Acquisition of the Technology Assets of LinguaSys, a Leading Provider of Natural Language Understanding (NLU) and Interactive Text Response (ITR) Technology]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/southflorida/news/2015/08/12/linguasys-tech-tools-acquired-by-cloud-service.html|title=https://www.bizjournals.com/southflorida/news/2015/08/12/linguasys-tech-tools-acquired-by-cloud-service.html|website=www.bizjournals.com|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref>
==Products and services== LinguaSys uses interlingual natural language processing software to provide multilingual text, sentiment, relevance and conceptual understanding and analysis.<ref>[http://www.federalnewsradio.com/137/3341736/Industry-Chatter-Brian-Garr-LinguaSys Industry Chatter: Brian Garr, LinguaSys - FederalNewsRadio.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.drdobbs.com/tools/new-natural-language-processing-api-port/240169200 "New Natural Language Processing API Portal"] ''Dr. Dodds''. by Adrian Bridgwater, October 22, 2014</ref> LinguaSys trademarked its proprietary interlingual technology called Carabao Linguistic Virtual Machine.<ref name="NeusteinMarkowitz2013">{{cite book|author1=Amy Neustein|author2=Judith A. Markowitz|title=Where Humans Meet Machines: Innovative Solutions for Knotty Natural-Language Problems|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FYBDAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA55|date=22 June 2013|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-1-4614-6934-6|pages=55–}}</ref> LinguaSys' multilingual software solutions are customized by clients and used via SaaS and behind the firewall. LinguaSys is an IBM Business Partner.
LinguaSys' multilingual technology is used on enterprise servers and consumer smartphones.<ref>[http://www.multilingual.com/newsDetail.php?id=8462 MultiLingual: LinguaSys teams with Salesforce.com @multilingualMag<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.southfloridasunrise.com/article/salesforcecom-adds-linguasys-social-insights-ecosystem Salesforce.com adds LinguaSys to social insights ecosystem | South Florida Sunrise<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
LinguaSys has developed an app ''TGPhoto'' which allows the user to snap a photo of some text and show a translation to one of fifty languages.<ref>[http://www.nypost.com/p/news/business/app_allows_you_to_point_shoot_translate_p8xs6YfgSt6McmuuSyAXhO App allows you to point, shoot & translate | New York Post<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://content.usatoday.com/communities/technologylive/post/2010/12/tgphoto-app-translates-signs-in-foreign-languages/1#.Ud3SR6yLaYJ TGPhoto app translates signs in foreign languages<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The software works on Android, and Blackberry smartphones.<ref>[http://content.usatoday.com/communities/technologylive/post/2010/12/tgphoto-app-translates-signs-in-foreign-languages/1#.VPc16eF0elo "TGPhoto app translates signs in foreign languages"]. by Edward C. Baig, ''USA TODAY''. 2010-12-08</ref>

In lunar photography, the '''Looney 11 rule''' (also known as the '''Looney f/11 rule''') is a method of estimating correct [[exposure (photography)|exposures]] without a [[light meter]]. For daylight photography, there is a similar rule called the [[Sunny 16 rule]].
The basic rule is, ''"For astronomical photos of the Moon's surface, set [[aperture]] to {{f/|11|link=yes}} and [[shutter speed]] to the [reciprocal of the] ISO [[film speed]] [or ISO setting]."'' * With ISO 100 film / setting in the camera, one sets the aperture to f/11 and the shutter speed to 1/100 or 1/125 second (on some cameras 1/125 second is the available setting nearest to 1/100 second). * With ISO 200 film / setting and aperture at f/11, set shutter speed to 1/200 or 1/250. * With ISO 400 film / setting and aperture at f/11, set shutter speed to 1/400 or 1/500.
As with other light readings, shutter speed can be changed as long as the f-number is altered to compensate, e.g. 1/250 second at f/8 gives equivalent exposure to 1/125 second at f/11. Generally, the adjustment is done such that for each step in aperture increase (i.e., decreasing the f-number), the exposure time has to be halved (or equivalently, the shutter speed doubled), and vice versa. This follows the more general rule derived from the mathematical relationship between aperture and exposure time—within reasonable ranges, exposure is proportional to the square of the aperture ratio and proportional to exposure time; thus, to maintain a constant level of exposure, a change in aperture by a factor ''c'' requires a change in exposure time by a factor 1/''c''² and vice versa. Steps in aperture correspond to a factor close to the square root of two, thus the above rule.
The intensity of visible sunlight striking the surface of the Moon is essentially the same as at the surface of the Earth. The [[albedo]] of the Moon's surface material is lower (darker) than that of the earth's surface, and the Looney 11 rule increases exposure by one stop versus the Sunny 16 rule. Many photographers simply use the f/16-based [[Sunny 16 rule]], unmodified, for lunar photographs.<ref>{{cite book | title = A Beginner's Guide to DSLR Astrophotography | author = Jerry Lodriguss | url = http://www.astropix.com/BGDA/BGDA.HTM }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title = A Guide to Astrophotography with Digital SLR Cameras | author = Jerry Lodriguss | url = http://www.astropix.com/GADC/GADC.HTM }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title = A Guide to DSLR Planetary Imaging | author = Jerry Lodriguss | url = http://www.astropix.com/GDPI/GDPI.HTM }}</ref>

'''Marimba 2010''' was a three-day international festival and conference hosted at the [[University of Minnesota]]. Running from April 28 to May 1, 2010, the event celebrated the music of the [[marimba]], and brought together around 45 world-class artists and ensembles.<ref>http://marimba2010.org</ref> University of Minnesota's director of percussion studies Fernando Meza hosted and directed the festival.<ref>[http://music.umn.edu/directory/facProfiles/MezaFernando.php ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100119181512/http://music.umn.edu/directory/facProfiles/MezaFernando.php |date=January 19, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.umn.edu/news/features/2010/UR_CONTENT_185946.html |title=The magic of marimbas : UMNews : University of Minnesota |publisher=.umn.edu |date=2010-04-21 |accessdate=2013-09-22}}</ref> [[Image:Marimba2010.jpg|thumb|alt=caption|Marimba 2010 Logo]]
==Performing Artists== Notable performing artists included the following: * [http://www.andrewbeall.com Andrew Beall], USA * Ivana Bilic, Croatia * [[Pius Cheung]], China/Canada * Eriko Daimo, Japan * Momoko Kamiya, Japan * [[Nanae Mimura]], Japan * [[William Moersch]], USA * [[Katarzyna Mycka]], Poland * Eric Sammut, France * Paul Smadbeck, USA * Kai Stensgaard, Denmark * [[Gordon Stout]], USA * Svet Stoyanov, Bulgaria * She-e Wu, Taiwan/USA * [[Nancy Zeltsman]], USA * Nebojsa Zivkovic, Serbia
A complete list of performing artists is located at http://marimba2010.org/artists.
==World Premieres== Marimba 2010 also saw the world premieres of a number of pieces featuring the marimba.<ref name="Fernando Meza">{{cite book|last=Meza|first=Fernando|title=Marimba 2010, International Festival and Conference (program guide)|year=2010|url=http://marimba2010.org}}</ref> These include the following: * ''Fernando's Waltz'', Paul Smadbeck * ''Like Blind Man Tapping in the Dark'', Libby Larsen (performed by William Moersch and Svet Stoyanov) * ''Dreaming of the Red Chamber'', Chien-Hui Hung (performed by Pei-Ching Wu) * ''Hexagram'', Kai Stensgaard * ''Blossoms in the Sunlight'', Takatsugu Muramatsu (performed by Momoko Kamiya) * ''Spirit'', Takatsugu Muramatsu (performed by Momoko Kamiya) * ''Hato Oto'', Hirotake Kitakata (performed by Momoko Kamiya) * ''The Plum Blossoms'', Eiko Orita (performed by Mutsuko and Rika Fuji) * ''Visions'', Stephen Paulus (performed by She-e Wu, Angel Frette, Ivana Blic, and Fernando Meza) * ''The Pilgrims' Hymn'', Stephen Paulus (performed by Nanae Mimura and Nancy Zeltsman) * ''Aquí ha nacido el tiempo'', Jorge Córdoba (performed by Marimba Nandayapa)
==Featured Presentations== One of the major performances highlighted at Marimba 2010 was a performance in conjunction with [[VocalEssence]]. The concert, entitled ''Mallets & Melodies'', was held in the [[Cathedral of Saint Paul, National Shrine of the Apostle Paul|Cathedral of St. Paul]], and combined the sound of the marimba with the sound of a choir. The headlining piece was Giovanni Gabrieli's Magnificat á 33, which features 20 marimbas, 30 marimba players, and a choir.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vocalessence.org/marimbas |title=Mallets & Melodies |publisher=VocalEssence |date=2010-04-30 |accessdate=2013-09-22}}</ref>
==Sponsors and Partners== Marimba 2010 was presented in conjunction with the [[Minnesota Orchestra]], the [[Saint Paul Chamber Orchestra]], the [[University of Minnesota]], [[VocalEssence]], [[Minnesota Public Radio]], the [[Schupert Club]], the [[Weisman Art Museum]], [[The Southern Theater]], the Minnesota Percussion Association, and numerous other organizations.<ref>[http://marimba2010.org/sponsors ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101029161744/http://marimba2010.org/sponsors |date=October 29, 2010 }}</ref>

{{Medieval and Renaissance literature}} {{National Literary "Matters"}} According to the [[Middle Ages|medieval]] [[poetry|poet]] [[Jean Bodel]], the '''Matter of Rome''' was the [[literature cycle|literary cycle]] made up of [[Greek mythology|Greek]] and [[Roman mythology]], together with episodes from the history of [[classical antiquity]], focusing on military heroes like [[Alexander the Great]] and [[Julius Caesar]]. Bodel divided all the literary cycles he knew best into the [[Matter of Britain]], the [[Matter of France]] and the Matter of Rome (although "non-cyclical" [[Romance (heroic literature)|romance]] also existed).<ref>{{Citation | first = Laura A | last = Hibbard | title = Medieval Romance in England | place = New York | publisher = Burt Franklin | year = 1963 | page = iii}}.</ref> The Matter of Rome also included what is referred to as the Matter of Troy, consisting of romances and other texts based on the [[Trojan War]] and its after-effects, including the adventures of [[Aeneas]].<ref name=Fowler>{{cite book|last=Fowler|first=Robert|title=The Cambridge Companion To Homer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K5WQRBvMp18C&pg=PA364|accessdate=21 July 2012|year=2004|publisher=Cambridge UP|isbn=9780521012461|page=364}}</ref>
==Subject matter== Classical topics were the subjects of a good deal of [[Old French]] literature, which in the case of Trojan subject matter ultimately deriving from [[Homer]] was built on scant sources; since the ''[[Iliad]]'' and the ''[[Odyssey]]'' were unknown, medieval Western poets had to make do with two short prose narratives based on Homer, ascribed to [[Dictys Cretensis]] and [[Dares Phrygius]]. The paucity of original text did not prevent the 12th century Norman poet [[Benoît de Sainte-Maure]] from writing a lengthy adaptation, ''Le Roman de Troie'', running 40,000 lines.<ref name=Fowler/> The poems that were written on these topics were called the ''romans d'antiquité'', the "romances of antiquity." This name presages the [[anachronism|anachronistic]] approach the medieval poets used in dealing with these subjects. For example, in the [[Epic poetry| epic]] poems ''[[Roman d'Alixandre]]'' and the ''[[Roman de Troie]]'', Alexander the Great, and [[Achilles]] and his fellow heroes of the [[Trojan War]] were treated as knights of [[chivalry]], not much different from the heroes of the ''[[chanson de geste|chansons de geste]]''.<ref>W. P. Ker, ''Epic And Romance: Essays on Medieval Literature'' p 27</ref> Elements of [[courtly love]] were introduced into the poems; in the ''[[Roman de Thèbes]]'', a romantic relationship absent from the [[Greek language|Greek]] sources is introduced into the tale of [[Parthenopeus| Parthenopæus]] and [[Antigone]]. Military episodes in these tales were also multiplied, and used to introduce scenes of [[knight-errant]]ry and [[tournament (medieval)|tournaments]].
Another example of French medieval poetry in this genre is the [[Roman d'Enéas|''Eneas'']], a treatment of the ''[[Aeneid]]'' that comes across as being a sort of burlesque of [[Virgil]]'s poem. Sentimental and fantasy elements in the source material were multiplied, and incidents from [[Ovid]], the most popular Latin poet of the Middle Ages, were mixed into the [[pastiche]]. The ''Philomela'' attributed to [[Chrétien de Troyes]], a retelling of the story of [[Philomela (princess of Athens)|Philomela]] and [[Procne]], also takes its source from Ovid's ''[[Metamorphoses (poem)|Metamorphoses]]''.
[[Geoffrey Chaucer]]'s ''[[Troilus and Criseyde]]'' is an English example, with Chaucer adding many elements to emphasize its connection with the matter.<ref name = "Lewis">{{Citation | authorlink = C. S. Lewis | first = Clive Staples | last = Lewis | title = Selected Literary Essays | publisher = University Press | place = Cambridge, ENG, UK | year = 1969}}.</ref>{{rp |30–1}} He also brought the story into line with the precepts of [[courtly love]].<ref name = "Lewis" />{{rp |35–6}}
This anachronistic treatment of elements from Greek mythology is similar to that of the [[Middle English]] [[narrative poetry|narrative poem]] "[[Sir Orfeo]]", where the Greek [[Orpheus]] becomes the knight Sir Orfeo who rescues his wife Heurodis (i.e. [[Eurydice]]) from the [[fairy]] king.

{{Infobox prepared food | name = Mujaddara | image = Mujaddara.jpg | caption = A style of Mujaddara | alternate_name = | country = [[Iraq]] | region = [[Iraq]], [[Lebanon]], [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], [[Syria]], [[Jordan]] and [[Israel]] | creator = | course = Main | type = | served = | main_ingredient = Rice or [[bulgur]], [[lentils]], onions | variations = | calories = | other = }} '''Mujaddara''' ({{lang-ar|مجدرة}} ''mujadarah'', with alternative spellings in English '''majadra''', '''mejadra''', '''moujadara''', '''mudardara''', and '''megadarra''') consists of cooked [[lentil]]s together with [[groat (grain)|groats]], generally [[rice]], and garnished with sautéed [[onion]]s.
==Name and origin== ''Mujaddara'' is the Arabic word for "pockmarked"; the lentils among the rice resemble pockmarks.<ref name=Basanp118>[https://books.google.com/books?id=-7wnpIi3VRwC&pg=PA118&dq=mujaddara&hl=en&ei=bSyzS5-pFIOe_AaD79n8CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=mujaddara&f=false Middle Eastern Kitchen], Ghillie Basan, p. 118.</ref><ref name=Marksp412/> The first recorded recipe for ''mujaddara'' appears in ''[[Muhammad bin Hasan al-Baghdadi|Kitab al-Tabikh]]'', a cookbook compiled in 1226 by [[Muhammad bin Hasan al-Baghdadi|al-Baghdadi]] in [[Iraq]].<ref name=Marksp412>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ojc4Uker_V0C&pg=PA412&dq=lentil+rice+medieval+arab&hl=en&ei=au_TTrL7N8Ta8QPD8cH6Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CD8Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=lentil%20rice%20medieval%20arab&f=false ''Encyclopedia of Jewish Food''], Gil Marks, p. 412.</ref> Containing rice, lentils, and meat, it was served this way during celebrations.<ref name=Marksp412/> Without meat, it was a medieval [[Arab cuisine|Arab dish]] commonly consumed by the poor, reputed to be a derivative of the "[[mess of pottage]]" [[Jacob]] used to buy [[Esau]]'s birthright.<ref name=Basanp118/> Because of its importance in the diet, a saying in the Eastern Arab world is, "A hungry man would be willing to sell his soul for a dish of mujaddara."<ref name=Salloump199>[https://books.google.com/books?id=pkmdosckh7MC&pg=PA199&dq=mujaddara&hl=en&ei=b-zTTt-dOIji8QOYlLXUDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=mujaddara&f=false ''From the lands of figs and olives: over 300 delicious and unusual recipes from the Middle East and North Africa''], Habeeb Salloum and Jim Peters, p. 199.</ref>
==Variations== Cooked lentils are popular all over the [[Middle East]] and form the basis of many dishes. ''Mujaddara'' is a popular dish throughout the [[Arab world]], and is generally made using brown or green lentils and rice, that can be seasoned with [[cumin]], [[coriander]], or [[Mentha|mint]].<ref name=Basanp118/> It is topped with fried onions and is generally served with yogurt, among other vegetables and side dishes, either hot or cold.<ref name=Basanp118/>
The dish is made with brown lentils and rice. In Lebanon, the word ''mjaddara'' refers to the puréed version of the dish, rather than the version with whole grains and lentils.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mjaddara or mdardara?|url=https://www.oroom.org/forum/threads/mjaddara-or-mdardara.44811/|website=The Orange Room|accessdate=26 August 2016}}</ref> ''Mjaddara'' usually has the consistency of rice pudding whereas in the [[Lebanese cuisine|Lebanese]] variant known as ''mudardara'', the rice and lentils remain relatively intact and distinct. Both ''mujaddara'' and ''mudardara'' are topped with caramelized onions and usually served with yogurt.
Particularly in [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], rice is often replaced with bulgur; the dish is called M'jaddaret-Burghul to distinguish it from the M'jaddara which is served with rice. Pronounced as ''m'jaddara'', the dish is served multiple times a month for family, cooked with olive oil and onion strips, and served alongside local plain sheep's-milk yogurt (laban n'aj) made in Nablus, with green salad.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hassoun|first1=Ghazi|title=Walking Out into the Sunshine: Recollections and Reflections: A Palestinian Personal Experience|url=https://books.google.ch/books?id=XypgDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT23&lpg=#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=BookBaby|language=en|date=10 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=UN World Food Programme|url=https://www.wfp.org/stories/familychef-samars-mujaddara|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=rice|first1=Mujaddara (Palestinian|last2=Says|first2=Lentil Dish /|title=Mujaddara palestinian rice & lentil dish|url=http://happiness-is-homemade.com/2014/08/18/mujaddara-palestinian-rice-lentil-dish/|website=Happiness is homemade|date=18 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Kitchen of Palestine Bulgur with Lentils (Mjaddara)|url=http://www.kitchenofpalestine.com/mjaddara/|website=www.kitchenofpalestine.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Zaytoun|url=http://www.zaytoun.org/downloads/recipes/Maftoul%20oil%20UM%20HIKMAT.pdf.|website=www.zaytoun.org}}</ref>
[[Arab Christians]] traditionally eat ''mujaddara'' during Lent.<ref name=Basanp118/> The dish is also popular among [[Mizrahim|Jewish communities of Middle Eastern origin]], in particular those of [[Syrian Jews|Syrian]] and [[History of the Jews in Egypt|Egyptian]] backgrounds; it is generally made with rice rather than wheat. It is sometimes nicknamed "Esau's favourite".<ref>Roden.</ref> Jews traditionally ate it twice a week: hot on Thursday evening, and cold on [[Sunday]].<ref>Dweck, Poopa, ''Aromas of Aleppo''.</ref>
==Similar dishes== In [[Egyptian cuisine]], lentils, rice, [[macaroni]], and tomato sauce cooked together are known as [[kushari]]. In Indian cuisines, lentils cooked together with rice are known as [[khichdi]] (see also [[kedgeree]]). In [[Iranian cuisine]], a similar dish composed of rice and lentils is called Addas Polo.
In Cypriot cuisine, the dish called "fakes moutzentra"<ref name=CFVM>{{cite web|last1=Yangou|first1=Varvara|title=Φακές μουτζιέντρα|url=http://foodmuseum.cs.ucy.ac.cy/web/guest/parsintages/civitem/2342#_bs_civitems_tabcyprus.rec.tab1|website=foodmuseum.cs.ucy.ac.cy|publisher=Cyprus Food Virtual Museum|accessdate=30 November 2015|language=Greek}}</ref> is very similar to mujaddara, as it consists of lentils and rice. In Greek, "fakes" means lentils.
==References== <references/>

{{short description|2006 psychological horror film by Hans Horn}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Open Water 2 | image = Adriftposter7.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = Hans Horn | producer = {{Plainlist| Hi * [[Dan Maag]] * Philip Schulz-Deyle}} | writer = {{Plainlist| * Adam Kreutner * David Mitchell}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Eric Dane]] * [[Susan May Pratt]] * [[Richard Speight, Jr.]] * Niklaus Lange * [[Ali Hillis]] * [[Cameron Richardson]]}} | music = Gerd Baumann | cinematography = Bernhard Jasper | editing = Christian Lonk | studio = {{Plainlist| * Orange Pictures * Peter Rommel Productions * Shotgun Pictures}} | distributor = [[Universum Film A.G.]] | released = {{Film date|df=y|2006|07|10|[[Cambridge Film Festival|Cambridge]]|2006|08|10|Germany}} | runtime = 94 minutes | country = Germany | language = English | budget = $1.2 million | gross = $6.8 euros million<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?id=_fOPENWATER201&country=UK&wk=2006W35&id=_fOPENWATER201&p=.htm | title=Open Water 2: Adrift (2006) | work=[[Box Office Mojo]] | publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]] | accessdate=8 April 2015}}</ref> }} '''''Open Water 2: Adrift''''' (called '''''Adrift''''' in the UK, Australia, and various other countries, and called '''''Open Water 2''''' in Germany) is a 2006 [[psychological]] [[horror film|horror]] film filmed entirely in [[Malta]], starring [[Eric Dane]], [[Susan May Pratt]], [[Richard Speight, Jr.]], Niklaus Lange, [[Ali Hillis]], and [[Cameron Richardson]]. Promotional posters claim the film is based on actual events.
The script was written before ''[[Open Water (film)|Open Water]]'' (2003) was theatrically released. After ''Open Water'' became a success, ''Adrift'' was produced and the name was changed to ''Open Water 2: Adrift'' in some countries to capitalize on the success of the earlier film.
==Plot== A group of friends, Amy ([[Susan May Pratt]]), James ([[Richard Speight, Jr.]]), Zach (Niklaus Lange), Lauren ([[Ali Hillis]]), Dan ([[Eric Dane]]), and Dan's new girlfriend Michelle ([[Cameron Richardson]]) go for a weekend cruise on Dan's new yacht. Amy and James also bring their infant daughter, Sarah.
Most of the friends decide to jump into the water for a swim. Amy, who is hydrophobic after a childhood incident, refuses but Dan picks her up and dives in with her. However, nobody thought to lower the ladder to re-board the ship, and so everyone (except the baby) is trapped in the water with only two masks, a dive knife, and a toy dolphin float. Despite their efforts, the side of the yacht is too smooth to climb and the deck is too high to reach. They see a boat of teenagers heading towards them. The group try to grab their attention, but the teenagers think that they are just greeting them, and sail off. During the struggle, the group try using a phone to call for help, only to hear the voices of some well wishers, unable to get the caller's attention. The phone accidentally gets knocked in the water.
They are left to tread water disconsolately. The group resorts to removing and using their bathing suits to make a rope. After a couple of attempts they manage to get one end of the rope wrapped around a railing. Instead of having the lightest person climb up, Zach attempts to climb. He pulls himself up and his fingers brush the [[gunwale]] but the makeshift rope rips apart as he is too heavy. The group are now mostly naked and have only a partial rope.
Meanwhile, James goes underwater, and is fooling around with the prop, in an attempt to remove it and use it as a grappling hook, but he drops the knife. He swims down after it and manages to catch it, and desperately tries to swim for the surface. As he swims back up he crashes into the bottom of the boat, and is knocked unconscious. He resurfaces motionlessly and slightly bloodied with an apparent [[skull fracture]]. Zach gets the knife from James and starts stabbing the boat to climb back up. Dan tries to stop Zach, but accidentally stabs him, causing Zach to drop the knife.
In a fit of hysteria and fearing that sharks will be attracted by the blood, Michelle begins to swim away, but sinks underwater. Dan swims after her and sees her lifeless body drifting underwater. He dives after her, but he can't reach her, and her body disappears into the depths. After some time, Zach dies from blood loss in Lauren's arms. She reluctantly lets go of his body which floats away, face down. After much waiting, Lauren says she refuses to die treading water and attempts to swim back to shore to find help. Her fate after this is unknown.
Later that night, during a rainstorm, James dies from his head injury. Dan unsuccessfully searches underwater for the knife. He slams his mask on the hull in frustration and the [[Lens (optics)|lens]] pops out. Remembering Zach's attempt with the knife, Dan uses it to wedge in the crevice of the side door for the ladder, giving him a handhold. Amy climbs over his shoulders, finally stepping onto his hand wrapped around the lens,causing him to yell as his hand bleeds more and manages to grab the gunwale and pull herself back on board. Once on board, she lowers the ladder for Dan and tends to her baby, Sarah. Amy notices Dan swimming away to drown out of guilt. She jumps back in to save him, reminding her of when she attempted to save her father in the same manner, at a young age.
The next morning, a fishing boat approaches the yacht, and notices the lowered ladder and life ring still floating in the water - no one had pulled them in. The yacht appears empty except for the sound of Sarah crying on the lower deck.
The film cuts to Amy standing on the boat in the sun, looking around appearing heartbroken. Dan is shown lying face down on the boat with a towel covering his lower half, seemingly sleeping.
==Cast== * [[Susan May Pratt]] as Amy ** Alexandra Raach as young Amy * [[Eric Dane]] as Dan * [[Richard Speight Jr.]] as James * Niklaus Lange as Zach * [[Ali Hillis]] as Lauren * [[Cameron Richardson]] as Michelle * Wolfgang Raach as Amy's father
==Reception==
===Critical response=== {{Anchor|Critics}} ''Open Water 2: Adrift'' received mixed reviews from critics. Review aggregate website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gave the film an overall score of 40% based on 10 reviews.<ref>{{rotten-tomatoes|id=open_water_2|title=Open Water 2: Adrift}}</ref>
===Box office=== In the [[United Kingdom]], the film opened at 327 theaters, grossing £337,474, averaging £1,033 per theater.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/intl/uk/?yr=2006&wk=35&p=.htm |title=United Kingdom Box Office, September 1–3, 2006 |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=2010-08-20}}</ref> 123 theaters dropped the film for the second weekend, and its ticket sales declined by 75 percent, making £85,541, averaging £419.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/intl/uk/?yr=2006&wk=36&p=.htm |title=United Kingdom Box Office, September 8–10, 2006 |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=2010-08-20}}</ref> During the third weekend, the film's sales tumbled 90 percent after 183 more theaters dropped it, making £8,896.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/intl/uk/?yr=2006&wk=37&p=.htm |title=United Kingdom Box Office, September 15–17, 2006 |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=2010-08-20}}</ref> The fourth weekend brought an additional 64 percent decline, and the film lost 13 theaters, while grossing £3,198.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/intl/uk/?yr=2006&wk=38&p=.htm |title=United Kingdom Box Office, September 22–24, 2006 |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=2010-08-20}}</ref> In the UK, the film finished with an overall gross of £707,352.
In [[Germany]], the film's opening weekend brought €293,601, averaging €3,764 at 78 theaters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/intl/germany/?yr=2006&wk=32&p=.htm |title=Germany Box Office, August 10–13, 2006 |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=2010-08-20}}</ref> During the second weekend in Germany, the film grossed €121,997, averaging €1,564 at 78 theaters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/intl/germany/?yr=2006&wk=33&p=.htm |title=Germany Box Office, August 17–20, 2006 |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=2010-08-20}}</ref> In Germany, the movie grossed at least €496,357.
In [[Spain]], the film's opening weekend earned €270,396, averaging €1,767 at 153 theaters. During the second weekend, the film grossed €139,503. In Spain, the film grossed at least €713,834.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/intl/spain/?yr=2006&wk=35&p=.htm |title=Spain Box Office, September 1–3, 2006 |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=2010-08-20}}</ref>
The film has grossed £2,583,205 worldwide.

The '''philosophy of technology''' is a sub-field of [[philosophy]] that studies the nature of [[technology]] and its social effects.
Philosophical discussion of questions relating to technology (or its Greek ancestor ''[[techne]]'') dates back to the very dawn of [[Western philosophy]].<ref name="Franssen et al." /> The phrase "philosophy of technology" was first used in the late 19th century by German-born philosopher and geographer [[Ernst Kapp]], who published a book titled "Grundlinien einer Philosophie der Technik".<ref name="Marquit 1995">{{cite web|last1=Marquit|first1=Erwin|title=Philosophy of Technology|url=http://www.tc.umn.edu/~marqu002/techphil.html|accessdate=25 September 2015|date=1995}} Section 2, paragraph 10. Published in vol. 13 of the ''Encyclopedia of Applied Physics'' (entry “Technology, Philosophy of”), pp. 417–29. VCH Publishers, Weinheim, Germany, 1995.</ref><ref name="Kapp 1877" />
== History ==
=== Greek philosophy === The western term 'technology' comes from the Greek term ''[[techne]]'' (τέχνη) (art, or craft knowledge) and philosophical views on technology can be traced to the very roots of [[Western philosophy]]. A common theme in the Greek view of ''techne'' is that it arises as an imitation of nature (for example, weaving developed out of watching spiders). Greek philosophers such as [[Heraclitus]] and [[Democritus]] endorsed this view.<ref name="Franssen et al.">{{cite journal |last1=Franssen |first1=Maarten |last2=Lokhorst |first2=Gert-Jan |last3=van de Poel |first3=Ibo |title=Philosophy of Technology |work=[[The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]] |date=Spring 2010 |first4=Edward N., Ed. |last4=Zalta |url=http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/spr2010/entries/technology/ |accessdate=May 15, 2014}}</ref> In his [[Physics (Aristotle)|Physics]], [[Aristotle]] agreed that this imitation was often the case, but also argued that ''techne'' can go beyond nature and complete "what nature cannot bring to a finish."<ref>Aristotle, Physics II.8, 199a15</ref> Aristotle also argued that nature (''physis'') and ''techne'' are ontologically distinct because natural things have an inner principle of generation and motion, as well as an inner teleological final cause. While ''techne'' is shaped by an outside cause and an outside ''[[Telos (philosophy)|telos]]'' (goal or end) which shapes it.<ref>Aristotle, Physics II</ref> Natural things strive for some end and reproduce themselves, while ''techne'' does not. In [[Plato]]'s [[Timaeus (dialogue)|Timaeus]], the world is depicted as being the work of a divine craftsman ([[Demiurge]]) who created the world in accordance with [[platonic forms|eternal forms]] as an artisan makes things using blueprints. Moreover, Plato argues in the [[Laws]], that what a craftsman does is imitate this divine craftsman.
=== Middle ages to 19th century === [[File:Francis Bacon, Viscount St Alban from NPG (2).jpg|thumb|right|Sir Francis Bacon]] During the period of the Roman empire and late antiquity authors produced practical works such as [[Vitruvius]]' ''[[De Architectura]]'' (1st century BC) and [[Georgius Agricola|Agricola]]'s ''[[De re metallica|De Re Metallica]]'' (1556). Medieval [[Scholastic philosophy]] generally upheld the traditional view of technology as imitation of nature. During the Renaissance, [[Francis Bacon]] became one of the first modern authors to reflect on the impact of technology on society. In his utopian work ''[[New Atlantis]]'' (1627), Bacon put forth an optimistic worldview in which a fictional institution ([[Salomon's House]]) uses [[natural philosophy]] and technology to extend man's power over nature - for the betterment of society, through works which improve living conditions. The goal of this fictional foundation is "...the knowledge of causes, and secret motions of things; and the enlarging of the bounds of human empire, to the effecting of all things possible".{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
=== 19th century ===
The native German philosopher and geographer [[Ernst Kapp]], who was based in [[Texas]], published the fundamental book "Grundlinien einer Philosophie der Technik" in 1877.<ref name="Kapp 1877">* [[Ernst Kapp]]: ''Grundlinien einer Philosophie der Technik. Zur Entstehungsgeschichte der Cultur aus neuen Gesichtspunkten'' (Braunschweig/Brunswick 1877, Reprint Düsseldorf 1978, Engl. Translation Chicago 1978).</ref> Kapp was deeply inspired by the philosophy of [[Hegel]] and regarded technique as a projection of human organs. In the European context, Kapp is referred to as the founder of the philosophy of technology.
Another, more materialistic position on technology which became very influential in the 20th-century philosophy of technology was centered on the ideas of [[Benjamin Franklin]] and [[Karl Marx]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}}
=== 20th century to present ===
Five early prominent 20th-century philosophers to directly address the effects of modern technology on humanity were [[John Dewey]], [[Martin Heidegger]], [[Herbert Marcuse]], [[Günther Anders]] and [[Hannah Arendt]]. They all saw technology as central to modern life, although Heidegger, Anders,<ref># The Outdatedness of Human Beings 1. On the Soul in the Era of the Second Industrial Revolution. 1956 # The Outdatedness of Human Beings 2. On the Destruction of Life in the Era of the Third Industrial Revolution.</ref> Arendt<ref>Hannah Arendt, ''The Human Condition'', 1958.</ref> and Marcuse were more ambivalent and critical than Dewey. The problem for Heidegger was the hidden nature of technology's essence, ''[[Gestell]]'' or ''Enframing'' which posed for humans what he called its greatest danger and thus its greatest possibility. Heidegger's major work on technology is found in ''[[The Question Concerning Technology]]''.
Contemporary philosophers with an interest in technology include [[Jean Baudrillard]], [[Albert Borgmann]], [[Andrew Feenberg]], [[Langdon Winner]], [[Donna Haraway]], [[Avital Ronell]], [[Brian Holmes]], [[Don Ihde]], [[Bruno Latour]], [[Paul Levinson]], [[Ernesto Mayz Vallenilla]], [[Carl Mitcham]], [[Leo Marx]], [[Gilbert Simondon]], [[Lewis Mumford]], [[Jacques Ellul]], [[Bernard Stiegler]], [[Paul Virilio]], [[Günter Ropohl]], [[Nicole C. Karafyllis]], [[Richard Sennett]], [[:pt:Álvaro Vieira Pinto|Álvaro Vieira Pinto]] and [[George Grant (philosopher)|George Grant]].
While a number of important individual works were published in the second half of the twentieth century, [[Paul Durbin]] has identified two books published at the turn of the century as marking the development of the philosophy of technology as an academic subdiscipline with canonical texts.<ref>[http://scholar.lib.vt.edu/ejournals/SPT/v7n1/intro.html Techné Vol 7 No 1]</ref> Those were ''Technology and the Good Life'' (2000), edited by [[Eric Higgs (philosopher)|Eric Higgs]], Andrew Light, and [[David Strong]] and ''American Philosophy of Technology'' (2001) by [[Hans Achterhuis]]. Several collected volumes with topics in philosophy of technology have come out over the past decade and the journals ''[[Techné: Research in Philosophy and Technology|Techne: Research in Philosophy and Technology]]'' (the journal of the [[Society for Philosophy and Technology]], published by the [[Philosophy Documentation Center]]) and ''Philosophy & Technology'' ([[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]]) publish exclusively works in philosophy of technology. Philosophers of technology reflect broadly and work in the area and include interest on diverse topics of geoengineering, internet data and privacy, our understandings of internet cats, technological function and epistemology of technology, computer ethics, biotechnology and its implications, transcendence in space, and technological ethics more broadly.
=== Technology and neutrality ===
[[Technological determinism]] is the idea that "features of technology [determines] its use and the role of a progressive society was to adapt to [and benefit from] technological change."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Green|first1=Lelia|title=Technoculture|date=2001|publisher=Allen & Unwin|location=Crows Nest, Australia|page=2}}</ref> The alternative perspective would be social determinism which looks upon society being at fault for the "development and deployment"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Green|first1=Lelia|title=Technoculture|date=2001|publisher=Allen & Unwin|location=Crows Nest, Australia|page=3}}</ref> of technologies. [[Lelia Green]] used recent gun massacres such as the [[Port Arthur massacre (Australia)|Port Arthur Massacre]] and the [[Dunblane Massacre]] to selectively show technological determinism and [[social determinism]]. According to Green, a technology can be thought of as a neutral entity only when the sociocultural context and issues circulating the specific technology are removed. It will be then visible to us that there lies a relationship of social groups and power provided through the possession of technologies.
